<<Accounts>>

Hey!

Thank you for choosing me as your personal guide. My name is Aitza and my mission is to make the path to sustainable financial freedom easy to understand, so you can increase your cash flow, slash your debt and gain time freedom.

<<Accounts>>

Your path starts here on MyBudgetCoach. 

What's cool about MyBudgetCoach, is that you don't have to do it alone. The support is built in and my digital avatar will be here each step of the way.

<<Accounts>>

Best part, if you ever want connect live you can book a one-on-one coaching session with me.

Simply head over here and click 'Schedule Zoom'. Then pick a time that works best!

<<Accounts>>

Otherwise, my digital avatar will be right here while you work through the setup flow. Cool right?

<<Accounts>>

Now, just because digital me will be here 24/7 doesn't mean you need to be. 

The mission is sustainable financial freedom. That means, go at your own pace, give yourself grace and take it one step at a time.
I need 5 minutes
I'm Ready!

<<Accounts>>

Are you ready to get started?

<<Accounts>>

Full transparency: The one-on-one coaching has an additional fee, but when it comes time to set up your budget we can include a line for that.

Because trust me... the money you're looking for is hidden in your expenses.
I'm Back

<<Accounts>>

No problem, I'll be here when you get back.

<<Accounts>>

In order to make this a truly personalized experience I'll need to ask you a few questions along the way to get to know you better and be able to guide you through the process.

No

Budget Summary Overview

<<Budget>>

Ok Wealth Builder! By now you have learned:
- about MyBudgetCoach
- how to add accounts
- how to navigate the accounts screen, AND
- how to enter transactions.

You might be wondering, well where is the budget? I'm happy to let you know... we're here!

<<Budget>>

Here you can see the current month as well as previous and future months.
move_to: months_band
I clicked calendar #3!

<<Budget>>

Let's say you want to compare several months at once. You can click on the calendars to view one, two, or three months at a time.
move_to: calendar_icons

<<Budget>>

Now you can view three months. Let's change the view so you can see a different set of months using the purple selection.
move_to: months_band

<<Budget>>

Below the current month, there are several pieces of information and an amount labeled "To Budget."

<<Budget>>

While you're getting to know MyBudgetCoach, just focus on the amount to budget for now.

<<Budget>>

Click on the number to see some options for this amount. There are multiple ways to move money around your budget. After all, it's meant to be flexible!

<<Budget>>

You can click anywhere on the screen to close this option menu. We'll move onto the next part!
Budget Table Overview

<<Budget>>

This is the budget table, basically a digital cash envelope system! You create categories relevant to your life and budget dollars accordingly.
move_to: budget_table

<<Budget>>

The Category column houses the names of each category group and category. We'll get customizing these in a bit.
move_to: category_column

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is where you'll be budgeting your dollars. This shows you what you have allocated each month for the categories.
move_to: budgeted_column

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows you the dollar total of all spending based on the transactions you have categorized.
move_to: spent_column
What happens if I don't cover the overspending?

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows you what you have available to spend.

Budgeted - Spent = Balance

If the amount is red, you've overspent in this category. If the amount is black, that's what you have available.
move_to: balance_column
Ok. I definitely don't want to do that!

<<Budget>>

If you don't cover overspending, you either risk overdrafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card. More on this later!

<<Budget>>

Take a look at the three dots to the right of the word 'Category'. This gives you visual options. You can collapse and expand category groups. You can also show and hide Hidden categories with the 'Show Hidden' option.
move_to: budget_category_three_dots

<<Budget>>

When you hover over a category group name (For example, the Usual Expenses), an arrow appears. You have options to add a category in this group, hide it, rename it or delete it.

<<Budget>>

Now, add a category to this group. Choose a regular monthly bill you pay, such as your rent or mortgage. Then click ENTER.
move_to: header_row_arrow

<<Budget>>

Amazing [[first_name]]! Now you have more insight into the budget screen AND how to add categories.

Add Transaction
(Bank Account)

Next up, let's practice manually adding a transaction on your account. Please click on your main checking account to get started!

<<Accounts>>

Note: For checking account transactions, payments DECREASE the balance and deposits INCREASE the balance.

<<Accounts>>

Click "+ Add New"

By clicking "Show running balance", a new column is added to the right. This shows the account balance after each transaction occurs. It will be useful for reconciling your account later.

<<Accounts>>

"Hide "cleared" checkboxes" removes the column that shows the cleared (green) and uncleared (grey) checkboxes next to your transactions.

<<Accounts>>

With "Export" you can download all of your transactions as a CSV file here. Great if you're into data, but not necessary for most users.

<<Accounts>>

"Reconcile" is a fancy word for making sure you're budgeting the right amount of dollars! It's important to regularly check your bank account and add transactions. We'll do this together soon.
Definitely looking forward to that!

<<Accounts>>

<<Budget>>

Please click on the third calendar icon.

(Note: Based on your zoom level, you might see less then three calendar icons, you can change your zoom level to change this.)

Personally, I like looking at my budget in 3-month windows, so that I can break things down by quarter. This isn't a requirement though. Remember this is YOUR sustainable budget.

<<Budget>>

The months highlighted in purple represent your current view. This will change as you click different months. With this feature you're able to see where you spent money in the past and plan ahead for future months. Click on a few different months to see the change in view.
I'm in single month view.

Now that you've been able to test out the different view options, let's go to a single month view by clicking the first calendar icon.
move_to: calendar_icons

<<Budget>>

If you're thinking to yourself, "I don't know how much to budget where?!" Know that feeling is normal when you start budgeting. This is also something I can help you with on a Zoom call.
Why hidden?

<<Budget>>

When you hover over a Category name, you'll see an arrow appear as well. This is because each of your categories can be hidden, renamed or deleted with the same arrow.

<<Budget>>

You can use the 'hide' feature for categories that are not used often or are no longer relevant. This maintains your ability to keep historical data stored for future reference and if you end up needing it again, you can just unhide it.
It's hidden

Let's give it a try. Hide the category you just created.

<<Budget>>

Now, to unhide it select the three dots again and select 'Show Hidden'.

<<Budget>>

Notice that it's back, but grayed out indicating it's hidden.

Something to keep in mind: You cannot delete categories that have previous transactions linked to it. You will be prompted to re-label those transactions in order to actually delete the category.
You can say that again!

<<Budget>>

For this reason, hiding the category is definitely the better option if it has previous transactions because...
Back like it never left

<<Budget>>

Budget Setup
Why do you call it a "YES! Plan"?

<<Budget>>

It's time to set up your "YES! Plan" (aka budget).
Understood. Thanks!

<<Budget>>

Ta-dah! I'm going to walk you through the format and then you can get to customizing.

 Reminder: While you can delete/hide any categories that don't apply, I ask that you do not modify the category names for the duration of the external coaching program.
ember_coaching = yes
ember_coaching = no
Great Thanks!

<<Budget>>

Ta-dah! I'm going to walk you through the format and then you can get to customizing.

Even though this is a template, you can still modify anything you need.
Ok - like rent or a car payment.

<<Budget>>

Great! So, the first category group is 'Fixed Expenses'. These are bills that you expect every month with (1) a set amount and (2) a set due date. The exception will be utilities that fluctuate based on usage.

<<Budget>>

Okay, I'm going to start you off with a budget template that I use for my clients. This way you won't need to build it from scratch.
Can you explain?

<<Budget>>

Correct.

Next we have 'Flexi'. These are account categories that you expect every month with (1) an amount that changes monthly and (2) no set due date, but you also might not spend in them at all.

They are also categories where you can adjust your spending behaviors if you need to reduce spend in one area to cover another.
That may come in handy! I always thought you couldnt change budgeted amounts.

<<Budget>>

For example, let's say you budget $200 for shopping but you are going to be short $50 for groceries. In your shopping flexi account you can reduce your budgeted amount by $50 and increase your groceries category by $50 without worrying that you won't have enough to cover a bill.
Got it!

<<Budget>>

Not at all! Just like your day-to-day life, your budget should have some wiggle room. This is why I find it useful to keep categories that are more flexible grouped together.

<<Budget>>

The next category group is Sinking Funds. These are recurring expenses that happen less frequently (i.e. once a quarter or once a year). Having this group allows you to set aside a little each month towards that upcoming expense.
move_to: sinking_funds
I love that I'm not putting myself last!

<<Budget>>

The third category is 'Future You'. The purpose of this category group is to set aside funds for your future self; think savings, investing, tithing, etc.

Thanks for that information. Direct Import within MyBudgetCoach has some great benefits. For example, the starting balance for linked accounts is automatically set and the system includes three prior days worth of transactions to get you started.

<<Accounts>>

Direct Import removes the additional tasks of having to manually upload transactions. Each time you log in, the system will automatically have added recent transactions.

<<Accounts>>

MyBudgetCoach uses machine learning, so as you continue to use the system, the system will automatically apply proposed categories to new transactions and the manual steps to categorize transactions will lessen over time.

<<Accounts>>

To increase your security, MyBudgetCoach has partnered with a third-party service, SimpleFIN, to link your accounts. SimpleFIN uses a well-established connection software called 'MX' to connect your bank account financial institutions to SimpleFIN.

<<Accounts>>

To connect SimpleFIN to MyBudgetCoach, there is a one-time code produced by SimpleFIN to enter into MyBudgetCoach. The accounts you link in SimpleFIN will then become available to link to already existing accounts within MyBudgetCoach to start Direct Import.

<<Accounts>>

Please note SimpleFIN does have a small additional fee: $1.50 per month, or $15 per year (not including tax, if applicable). This is paid separately from your MyBudgetCoach subscription and is paid through SimpleFIN, not within MyBudgetCoach.

Direct Import removes the additional task of having to manually upload transactions. Ech time you log in, the system will automatically have added recent transactions.
Nice; the system automates some of the set-up steps!

MyBudgetCoach uses machine learning, so as you continue to use the system, the system will automatically apply proposed categories to new transactions and the manual steps to categorize transactions wil lessen over time.
less steps for me? sign me up!

To increase your security, MyBudgetCoach has partnered with a third party service, SimpleFIN, to link your accounts. SimpleFIN uses a well stablished connection software called "MX" to connect your bank account financial institutions to SimpleFIN.
The system learns my spending habits? what a cool feature!

<< Accounts >>

To connect SimpleFIN to MyBudgetCoach, there is a one-time code produced by SimpleFin to enter into MyBudgetCoach. The accounts you link in SimpleFIN will then become available to add in MyBudgetCoach for Direct import.

Please note SimpleFin does have a small additional fee: $1.50 per month, or $15 dolar per year. This is charged in addition to your MyBudgetCoach subscription and is paid throught SimpleFIN, not within MyBudgetCoach.

When recreating a copy of your financial institution transactions and balance in MyBudgetCoach, one of the most important pieces is knowing how your 'Current Balance' is calculated by your bank.

<< Accounts >>

Some banks calculate the 'Current Balance' including pending transactions. Others calculate the 'Curent Balance' excluding pending transactions which means only cleared transactions are included

As we review earlier, MyBudgetCoach has an option to show 'Running Balance' in your account.
<font color="#000000" style="font-size: 13px;">YES</font>

<< Accounts >> 

A 'Running Balance' is the balance of your account after each transaction has cleared.
<font color="#000000" style="font-size: 13px;">Ok right! let me double check I have it turned on for this account. </font>

<< Accounts >> 

For example, if you have $500 in your bank account, and a $100 Payment is cleared, the 'Running Balance' for that transaction would be $400 ($500 - $100).
<font color="#000000" style="font-size: 13px;">Understood</font>

<< Accounts >> 

A 'Running Balance' allows you to select any date and compare MyBudgetCoach to your bank account balance. This is especially helpful when using bank account statements to verify the numbers shown in MyBudgetCoach are in-sync.
<font color="#000000" style="font-size: 13px;">That make sense!</font>

<< Accounts >> 

In addition to using the 'Running Balance' in MyBudgetCoach, it is very helpful to view the 'Running Balance' within your bank account.
<font color="#000000" style="font-size: 13px;">I will definitely keep this in mind.</font>

<< Accounts >> 

Unfortunately, some online websites and/or mobile apps, for banks don't offer the option of the 'Running Balance'. If your bank doesn't have the option, it can add complexity to reconciling your account if your numbers don't match up.
